justification: The methods state: "We assessed participant statistical numeracy ... with the four multiple choice questions from the Berlin Numeracy Test (Cokely et al., 2012) and scored them as correct or incorrect."
The article notes: "We also assessed number line estimation accuracy ... with 22 questions from a mental number line task, which included a slider ranging from 1 to 1000."

measured_by: binary amount similarity judgment questions (34 money pairs)
justification: Methods describe: "Binary amount similarity judgments involved 34 judgments between two monetary amounts ... participants indicated whether the pair was similar or dissimilar."

measured_by: binary delay similarity judgment questions (25 time-delay pairs)
justification: It is stated: "Binary delay similarity judgments (N=25) were comparable to the amount judgments but adapted for delays (e.g., 7 days vs. 14 days)."

measured_by: hypothetical intertemporal choice task (34 smaller-sooner vs. larger-later decisions)
justification: The procedure explains: "Intertemporal choices involved 34 hypothetical choices between smaller, sooner and larger, later payoffs (e.g., '11 dollars in 7 days or 13 dollars in 14 days?')."
